description: Learn to manage state globally without external libraries using React's built-in Context API.

slides.title: What is Context?
slides.content:
# The Context API üì°

Context provides a way to pass data through the component tree without having to pass props down manually at every level.

Great for global data:
- Current authenticated user.
- Type of language/locale.
- UI Theme (Dark/Light).

slides.title: Prop Drilling Problem
slides.content:
# Prop Drilling üï≥Ô∏è

Without Context, passing data from `App` to a deeply nested `Button` (e.g., App -> Layout -> Header -> UserMenu -> Button) requires passing `user={user}` to every intermediate component.

This is "Drilling". Context solves this teleportation.

slides.title: Creating Context
slides.content:
# createContext üõ†Ô∏è

First, create the context object.

```javascript
import { createContext } from 'react';

const ThemeContext = createContext('light'); // Default value
```

slides.title: Provider
slides.content:
# Provider üì°

Wrap the components that need access to the data.

```jsx
<ThemeContext.Provider value="dark">
  <Toolbar />
</ThemeContext.Provider>
```
`Toolbar` and ANY of its children can now access the value "dark".

slides.title: Component Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which component is required to MAKE data available to the tree?

slides.title: Consuming (hooks)
Multiple Contexts
slides.content:
# Multiple Contexts üìö

You can nest Providers to share different types of data.

```jsx
<AuthContext.Provider value={user}>
  <ThemeContext.Provider value={theme}>
    <Layout />
  </ThemeContext.Provider>
</AuthContext.Provider>
```

slides.title: Updating Context
Performance Caution
slides.content:
# Performance Warning ‚ö†Ô∏è

Every time the Provider's `value` changes, ALL consumers re-render.

If you pass a new object `{{ user }}` every time, it triggers re-renders on every parent render.

**Solution:** Use `useMemo` for the value object.

slides.title: Context vs Redux
slides.content:
# Context vs Redux ü•ä

**Context** is built-in and great for simple, low-frequency updates (Theme, User).

**Redux** is better for complex state logic, middleware, and high-frequency updates.

They can be used together!

slides.title: Hook Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which hook is used to access the context value?

slides.title: Code Example
Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Context üéì

No more prop drilling.

- **Create:** `createContext`.
- **Provide:** Wrap tree with `<Provider value={data}>`.
- **Consume:** Use `useContext` hook.
- **Hierarchy:** Data flows down.
- **Performance:** Watch out for unnecessary re-renders.
